images.copyright: Oxbow Bend on the Snake River, Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming (© DanitaDelimont.com/AWL Images/SuperStock)
images.title: Wild by law
images.caption: Oxbow Bend on the Snake River, Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming
images.desc: Beyond water, rivers carry life, history, and stories. They are nature's ever-moving contribution to our landscapes, flowing through lands and across time. One such gem is the Snake River, which winds through Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. A particularly stunning spot along this river is Oxbow Bend—featured in today's image—where calm waters reflect the towering Teton Range, and wildlife such as moose and bald eagles thrive. Here, water flows freely, unbound by concrete or commerce, protected by the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, signed on this day in 1968.

og.title: Oxbow Bend on the Snake River, Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming
og.desc: Beyond water, rivers carry life, history, and stories. They are nature's ever-moving contribution to our landscapes, flowing through lands…

images.copyright: Clark Range, Sierra Nevada, Yosemite National Park, California (© Robb Hirsch/TANDEM Stills + Motion)
images.title: Echoes from the Clark Range
images.caption: Clark Range, Yosemite National Park, California
images.desc: This year marks another milestone in the legacy of Yosemite National Park, a sanctuary protected since 1864 and celebrated for its awe-inspiring grandeur and ecological significance. Nestled in the heart of the Sierra Nevada, Yosemite's nearly 1,200 square miles cradle granite giants, cascading waterfalls, and ancient sequoias. Among its lesser-known treasures lies the Clark Range—the rugged, high-elevation spine seen in today's image. It was named after Galen Clark, Yosemite's first guardian and a pioneer of conservation.

og.title: Clark Range, Yosemite National Park, California
og.desc: This year marks another milestone in the legacy of Yosemite National Park, a sanctuary protected since 1864 and celebrated for its awe…

images.copyright: Koala in a eucalyptus tree, Great Otway National Park, Australia (© Jamie Lamb - elusive-images.co.uk/Getty Images)
images.title: Clinging to what matters
images.caption: Koala in the Great Otway National Park, Australia
images.desc: Amid the lush eucalyptus canopy of Great Otway National Park, koalas reign as sleepy sentinels of Australia's wild soul. Often misnamed 'koala bears,' these marsupials are actually closer to wombats and tend to be instantly recognizable by their stout, tailless bodies, fluffy ears, and velvety black noses.

og.title: Koala in the Great Otway National Park, Australia
og.desc: Amid the lush eucalyptus canopy of Great Otway National Park, koalas reign as sleepy sentinels of Australia's wild soul. Often misnamed…

images.copyright: The Rainbow Houses of Houten, Netherlands (© George Pachantouris/Getty Images)
images.title: Rainbow rides and quiet vibes
images.caption: The Rainbow Houses of Houten, Netherlands
images.desc: You won't find souvenir shops or tourist maps pointing the way—but follow the edge of Lake Rietplas in Houten, and you'll stumble upon one of the Netherlands' most unexpectedly photogenic sights. While many flock to Amsterdam's canals or Rotterdam's cube houses, this quiet commuter town offers its own architectural twist. Lined up like a mirage, the Rainbow Houses shimmer in bold, painterly hues—a residential block turned an understated cultural landmark.

og.title: The Rainbow Houses of Houten, Netherlands
og.desc: You won't find souvenir shops or tourist maps pointing the way—but follow the edge of Lake Rietplas in Houten, and you'll stumble upon one…

images.copyright: Town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy (© zpagistock/Getty Images)
images.title: A taste of Pienza
images.caption: The town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy
images.desc: Some towns evolve slowly over centuries. Pienza? It received a full rebrand in the 1400s from a pope who wanted to prove a point—and maybe show off a little. This tiny Italian town is perched above the Val d'Orcia, surrounded by rolling hills that look exactly like you think Tuscany should: cypress trees, winding dirt roads, the occasional sheep. It's peaceful. And then you step inside the town walls, and it gets clever.

og.title: The town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy
og.desc: Some towns evolve slowly over centuries. Pienza? It received a full rebrand in the 1400s from a pope who wanted to prove a point—and maybe…

images.copyright: Tank Lakes, Alpine Lakes Wilderness, Washington (© Austin Trigg/TANDEM Stills + Motion)
images.title: Weeding and wishing
images.caption: Astronomy Day and National Public Lands Day
images.desc: When the calendar lines up just right, you get a rare double feature: National Public Lands Day and Astronomy Day. It's a chance to explore the landscapes that ground us and the skies that inspire us—all within 24 hours.

og.title: Astronomy Day and National Public Lands Day
og.desc: When the calendar lines up just right, you get a rare double feature: National Public Lands Day and Astronomy Day. It's a chance to explore…

images.copyright: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana (© Donald M. Jones/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The fast and the furriest
images.caption: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana
images.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and turbo-charged feet, this tiny rodent proves that being 'least' is no reason to squirrel away your potential. Weighing less than a deck of cards and measuring under 10 inches from nose to tail, this species is North America's smallest chipmunk.

og.title: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana
og.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and…

images.title: Carved stones of courage
images.caption: Chittorgarh Fort, Rajasthan, India
images.desc: High on a hill rising over 590 feet in Rajasthan, India, Chittorgarh Fort spans approximately 690 acres. It stands as a proud witness to the valor of the famed warrior clans—the Rajputs. Their name comes from the Sanskrit 'rajaputra,' meaning 'son of a king,' and they are celebrated for their noble lineage and martial traditions across northern India. The fort's stone walls have witnessed centuries of courage, pride, and romance, remembered in the songs of Rajasthan's bards. According to legend, Bhim, a hero from the Hindu epic 'Mahabharata,' first laid its foundations.
